ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CONFERENCES ABROAD ATTENDED BY MINISTERS


    1. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Minister to state

    (a) how many conferences held abroad were attended by Ministers of the Singapore Government this year;

    (b) the nature and period of such conferences, and the names of Ministers who attended them;

Column: 2734



    (c) the cost to the Singapore Government to send these Ministers to such conferences; and

    (d) what has the Singapore Government benefited by representation at such conferences.

    The Chief Minister (Dr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer to

    (a) is four.

    The answer to (b) is:

    (1) The Singapore Constitutional Conference from 7th March to 14th April, attended by the Hon. Dr Lim Yew Hock, the Hon. Inche Abdul Hamid bin Haji Jumat and the Hon. Mr Chew Swee Kee.

    (2) The 40th session of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) Conference from 25th May, 1957, to 30th June, 1957, attended by the Hon. Dr Lim Yew Hock.

    (3) The Colombo Plan Consultative Committee Conference from 21st October, 1957, to 25th October, 1957, attended by the Hon. Mr J. M. Jumabhoy.

    (4) The Asian Regional Conference of the ILO in New Delhi from 13th November, 1957, to 26th November, 1957, attended by the Hon. Dr Lim Yew Hock.

    The answer to (c), on cost: Under (b) (1) the total cost is $64,773. This is the cost of the whole mission. Separate figures of the cost of sending the three Ministers are not available. Under (b) (2) the cost is $6,754; (b) (3) - $825 estimated, final amount not yet available; (b) (4) - $ 1,750 estimated.

    The answer to (d) is the benefits derived from ministerial representation at the Singapore Constitutional Conference are many. To mention only two, they include the new Constitution which will come into force next year and the creation of a separate Singapore citizenship within the Commonwealth. With regard to the ILO and Colombo Plan Conferences attended by Ministers, the benefits derived cannot be expressed in precise quantitative and monetary terms. I would emphasise, however, the considerable material benefits given under the Colombo Plan and the technical

Column: 2735

training and service advice given both under the Plan and under ILO auspices. Almost all participating countries send a minister to these conferences and Singapore cannot accept a lower level of representation for itself, either to say thank you for the benefits received or successfully to press its case for continued assistance or to explain, in the case of the ILO Conference, labour or social policies of this country.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Will the Hon. the Chief Minister state if his visits and those of the other Ministers overseas beyond what he has described were on their own or at the expense of the public revenue?

    The Chief Minister: Sir, ministers of some other countries do not of course have constitutional problems, so therefore in regard to the first part of the question, I do not think so. But in regard to the ILO and the Colombo Plan, when Ministers are on official visits they are in receipt of an allowance from the Government.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Sir, I do not think the Hon. the Chief Minister has understood my question, which is this: have our Ministers visited overseas at the public expense beyond what is mentioned here?

    The Chief Minister: The answer is no.

ASSISTANT SUPERINTENDENTS OF POLICE
(Appointments)


    3. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary to state as at 31st October, 1957-

    (a) the number of vacancies in the Police Force for Assistant Superintendents of Police;

    (b) how many Inspectors who are now in the Force passed the Part I Higher Services Examination and are eligible for promotion to the rank of A.S.P.;

    (c) how many of such qualified Inspectors have been promoted to be A.S.P's.; and

    (d) how many Inspectors who have not qualified under the Part I Higher Services Scheme have been promoted to the rank of A.S.P.

    The Acting Chief Secretary (Mr R. C. Hoffman): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of vacancies in the Police Force for Assistant Superintendents of Police is 24. There are eight Inspectors of Police eligible for promotion to this rank. None has yet been promoted but their cases are now being considered by the Public Service Commission. Over recent years, five Inspectors of Police have been promoted to the rank of A.S.P. although they have not passed all the examinations required under Part I of the Scheme of Service.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Can the Hon. the Chief Secretary tell us whether these promotions were made by the Commissioner of Police or the Public Service Commission, and why those five who were unqualified were promoted to become A.S.P's, while none of the qualified were promoted?

    Mr Hoffman: Mr Speaker, Sir, the promotions were made by the Public Service Commission, that is based on the recommendations of the Public Service Commission. The reason why no promotion has yet been made in regard to the Inspectors of Police who are already

Column: 2737

qualified for consideration for promotion is that their cases are now under consideration by the P.S.C. I should explain that these officers have only recently qualified for consideration for promotion.

    As regards the other part of the question, the five Inspectors of Police who have already been promoted, these promotions have been over recent years. There is provision for the promotion of such officers who have passed the majority of the examinations required to qualify for promotion but not all. They have been promoted on the grounds of outstanding work and qualities of leadership and courage normally expected of more senior officers.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, can the Hon. the Chief Secretary tell us whether these promotions are acting appointments or substantive Ones?

    Mr Hoffman: They are substantive appointments.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, are we to understand from the Hon. the Chief Secretary's reply that the higher a position a person holds in the Police Force, the more courageous he is?

    Mr Hoffman: I merely suggested that there are other considerations apart from that of passing exanimations written and otherwise.

REGISTRATION AS CITIZENS
(Hardship and inconvenience)


    4. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary whether he is aware of the hardship and inconvenience experienced by people seeking registration as Singapore citizens by allotting certain days for people with only certain surnames; and whether he will take early action to open registration on all days and at all centres irrespective of the surnames of the applicants.

    The Acting Chief Secretary (Mr R. C. Hoffman): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not aware of any hardship or inconvenience caused by the system of regisration

Column: 2738

by surnames. This system is in operation in two centres only, namely, the Central Registration Office in Fort Canning Road and the Chinese Chamber of Commerce premises, where registration is heaviest. The system is working well and ensures a speedy handling of applications. In all other centres where registration is not as heavy, the surname system has not been introduced. It is not proposed to change the present arrangements.

TEENAGERS
(Continuation of Studies)


    6. Mr William Tan asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware of an increasing number of teenagers who are not allowed to continue their studies in the Government and Government-Aided Secondary Schools; and what steps does he propose to take or has taken to absorb them in other educational establishments.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, this question involves a problem which cannot be solved by the Ministry of Education alone. It is an accepted fact that not every person can benefit from secondary education, and even of those who qualify for admission into secondary schools after passing a

Column: 2739

common qualifying examination many fall by the wayside before reaching School Certificate level.

    The problem involving the future of teenagers cannot be solved by absorbing them into educational institutions. For those who are not likely to benefit from secondary education, Government has provided trade schools and apprenticeship schemes. It will be the policy of Government to increase these institutions to meet this increasing problem.

    Mr William Tan: Will the Hon. Minister for Education explain that these principles can absorb all the overage teenagers?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Besides these educational institutions there is the Adult Education Council which deals with adult education. And as mentioned, the apprenticeship scheme is in operation and will absorb most of these overage students.

GENERAL HOSPITAL WARDS
(Plan to show whereabouts)


    8. Mr William Tan asked the Minister for Health whether he will consider putting up a plan at the entrance to every block in the General Hospital indicating the whereabouts of different wards and departments.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Chew Swee Kee) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, plans showing the whereabouts of each ward, unit, etc., are not only put up at the entrance of the blocks but also at the other vantage

Column: 2740

points such as the car park. There are also in addition direction indicators to the various wards and units in each block. The hon. Member will realise that the General Hospital is a very spread-out structure and in consequence any plan, however simplified, would be somewhat difficult to read by persons unaccustomed to reading plans.

    Mr William Tan: Will the Hon. The Minister for Health consider putting up plans in the Chinese language?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Sir, at present the plans are only in the English language. This is of course of an experimental nature in order to see whether persons normally educated in English at least would be able to follow directions of the plans. The general observations we have indicate that even such persons find it difficult to read the plans and, in consequence, seek assistance from members of the staff for directions to various points. Under these circumstances, it is doubtful whether displaying further plans in Malay, Chinese, Tamil and other languages would be of any useful assistance. The matter, however, will be reviewed when found necessary.

AIRPORT
(Announcements in Mandarin and Tamil)


    9. Mr William Tan asked the Minister for Communications and Works whether he will now consider arranging for announcements of the arrivals and departures of planes to be made in Mandarin and Tamil over the public-address system at the Singapore Airport, in addition to the languages now used.

    Mr Francis Thomas: Sir, the question of arranging for announcements to be made in Mandarin and Tamil over the public address system at the Singapore Airport of the arrivals and departures of aircraft has been under consideration for a number of months. The hon. Member for Tiong Bahru was invited as long ago as April this year to let me have details of what he had described as "many instances in which passengers

Column: 2741

missed their planes or went to the wrong plane just because they did not know English". I have received no such evidence either from the hon. Member or from any other source that passengers have been inconvenienced by the fact that announcements over the public address system are not made in Mandarin and Tamil. Until I do get such evidence, I am not prepared to direct that such announcements should be made.

    Mr William Tan: Why does the Hon. Minister for Communications and Works not check with the Information Bureau of the Singapore Airport that passengers actually have been inconvenienced? Whenever announcements are made in English or Malay, we find passengers rushing to the Information Bureau to ask whoever is in charge what the announcements say.

    Mr Speaker: The hon. Member should not make a speech.

    Mr Francis Thomas: Sir, the hon. Member must be aware that a question of this sort is not answered by the Minister from his private thoughts but that it is circulated to the officials to get full official accounts for reply; and of course the Airport authorities have been very fully questioned on this matter and the reply is based on the information given by them and by the airline operators, who naturally would themselves be concerned if their passengers failed to arrive at the aircraft. I am sure that the airline operators are fully satisfied at present that their passengers are not inconvenienced and do in fact arrive at the aircraft at the times and places that they should.

    Mr William Tan: Is it not a duty to check up whether passengers have been inconvenienced or not?

TERRITORIAL WATERS AND BEACHES
(Pollution)


    10. Mr Soh Ghee Soon asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he is aware of the pollution of the territorial waters and beaches of Singapore; whether he has ascertained the causes of such pollution; and what measures he will take to prevent such pollution.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, the question is in three parts. The answer to part one is yes. The answer to part two is the pollution is caused by the discharge of oily substances by vessels in waters around Singapore. And the answer to part three is the discharge of oily substances within port limits has been prohibited for many years. Action to prevent oily discharges within and outside territorial waters is now in hand.

SEAMEN'S REGISTRY BOARD
(Protest over composition)


    11. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry if he has received a letter of protest from the Singapore Chinese Seafarers' Association regarding the composition of the Seamen's Registry Board; what action he has taken or will take in the matter; and, in particular, if he will consider taking action whereby a Chinese from the Seamen's Unions and Associations may be included on the Board.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, I have received such a letter protesting that no Chinese has been nominated to represent seafarers on the Seamen's Registry Board. Incidentally I may say that I have received a similar letter from the Malay Seamen's Union, I believe, protesting that no Malay has been nominated to represent its seamen on the Board. Whilst I am willing, Sir, to consider proper representations at all times, I am disturbed at the communal line taken by the Chinese Seafarers' Association. However, for the information of the hon. Member, I may add

Column: 2743

that every effort was made to ensure that the seamen's interests as a whole receive the best representations possible on the Board. The hon. Member must realise that the law permits only three representatives of seamen on the Board, and it is my duty to ensure that persons best suited to advance the interests of seamen as a whole are put on the Board.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, is it not possible to widen the representation of this Board so that it may be fully representative, be he a Malay or a Chinese; and by the fact that there is no representation of a Malay or a Chinese, is that Board fully representative?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, it was the duty of the hon. Member when the Bill came up to this Assembly to point out that three members would not be sufficient to represent all races of seamen. However, Sir, the basis on which the Government always works is a non-communal basis and I always take into consideration the interests of seamen as a whole rather than the interests of any section of seamen.

SINGAPORE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY ELECTIONS

(AMENDMENT) BILL


10.26 a.m.
First Reading


    The Assistant Minister to the Chief Secretary (Mr M. P. D. Nair): Sir, I beg to introduce a Bill intituled the "Singapore Legislative Assembly Elections (Amendment) Bill" (Chapter 53 of the Revised Edition).

Column: 2745



    Bill presented and read the First tune.
Second Reading


    Mr Speaker: Second Reading, what day?

    Mr Nair: Now, Sir. Mr Speaker. Sir, I lay on the Table a Certificate of Urgency signed by His Excellency the Governor in respect of this Bill to enable this House to proceed with it through all its other stages today.

    Certificate of Urgency handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The Certificate is in order. Are typed copies of the Bill available?

    Mr Nair: Yes, Sir.

    Typed copies of the Bill handed in to the Clerk and distributed to hon. Members.

    Mr Speaker: Please proceed.

    Mr Nair: Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This Bill proposes amendments to the Singapore Legislative Assembly Elections Ordinance which are rendered necessary by the enactment of the Singapore Citizenship Ordinance, 1957. The present qualifications of electors are laid down in section 5 of the Singapore Legislative Assembly Elections Ordinance, part of which reads as follows:

    "...any person who-

    (a) is a citizen of the United Kingdom and Colonies by virtue of the provisions of the British Nationality Act, 1948, or was born in any of the States or territories now included in the Federation of Malaya o the Colony of Sarawak or the Colony of North Borneo or the State of Brunei; and

    (b) was ordinarily resident in the Colony on the 1st day of April in any year; and

    (c) was not less than twenty-one years of age on the 1st day of July in that year, shall be entitled to have his name entered or retained in a register of electors in that year."

    Singapore is to attain the status of the State of Singapore as a self-governing territory, and the Assembly will be a fully elected body when the Legislative Assembly elections under the new Constitution are held. They are expected to be held next year. Hon. Members will recall that at the sitting in October this Assembly approved the

Column: 2746

Singapore Citizenship Ordinance, a charter by which we have achieved what we longed for years - the creation of a status recognisable in all parts of the Commonwealth for all those who regard Singapore as their home and the object of their undivided loyalty.

    Those who are citizens by birth and descent have the right to vote. The proposed amendment to section 5 is very significant. Thousands of our adult population who, although not born in Singapore, have been resident here for long periods and have contributed to the prosperity of Singapore, and are enthusiastically becoming Singapore citizens and declaring their allegiance to Singapore. It is important that the new status of Singapore citizenship should carry with it the right to assist in the procedure of democratic government, and this Bill seeks to grant our new citizens their first democratic right-the right to vote for election of the people's representatives to sit in this House.

    The general purpose of this Bill, therefore, is to provide that the right to vote in the Legislative Assembly elections shall be granted to citizens of Singapore and to Singapore citizens only, in a self-governing Singapore, it is no longer desirable to offer voting rights to those whose bodies are in Singapore but whose hearts and minds are elsewhere. If the newly won Constitution for self-government is to be implemented in the spirit in which it was framed, it is essential that the hearts and minds of all people participating in the government of Singapore should be in Singapore itself, and that their outlook and undivided loyalty should be centred here. Therefore, voting rights should be accorded only to citizens of Singapore.

    Clause 2 (ii) of the amending Bill proposes that the relevant residential date shall be the first day of February instead of the first day of April. This is necessary in order that the work of preparing registers in 1958 should be commenced as early as possible. Paragraphs (iii) and (iv) are consequential to the previous amendment.

    Clause 3 proposes that only persons who are or who become citizens of

Column: 2747

Singapore on or before the first day of February 1958, and who are resident in an electoral division on that day, shall have their names included in the first register. The existing subsections (2) to (4) of section 10 of the Ordinance are deleted in order to avoid any delay in the completion of the registers. This simplified procedure is in conformity with that laid down in the Local Government Elections Ordinance, 1957.

    Clause 4 provides for the revision of the registers in each year following the year 1958.

    Clause 5 repeals the Singapore Legislative Assembly (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance, 1957.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): I second it.

    Question proposed.

10.35 a.m.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Speaker, Sir, of course we agree to this Bill to give the rights to the citizens but I think the more important thing is after the passing of this Bill we should see that citizens should be accorded their rights. I am talking about the executive acts of the Government. We have noted that with all the good intentions Government has, there are still many waiting for their turn to swear allegiance to Singapore. They wait in long queues; they wait for days. They wait for teams to go for them to swear allegiance, but they have to wait for a very long time.

    They want forms to sign up but there are not enough forms. Forms are taken out one by one by people who would want to fill up for them, but none is available for the public. Forms are sometimes sold, as alleged in the newspapers, at 50 cents or a dollar each.

    This is most unsatisfactory. Government must wake up to the need of the people. Everybody wants to register before 1st February. They must be given that opportunity. They want to exercise their vote. Let us give them that vote. They have shown their

Column: 2748

loyalty. It is up to Government after the passage of this Bill to see to it that every person who wants to be a Singapore citizen is accorded his full rights and not made to wait.

10.37 a.m.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck (Paya Lebar): Sir, while we are glad that the residential date should be 1st February, 1958, I cannot help but join our Party leader in stating that by publishing this date we shall increase the fears of the people who wish to be registered, fear from thinking that they may not be able to get themselves registered. I have asked for registration teams from the Central Registration Office to go out to some of the outlying areas and only last week when I asked for a date, I was told that the dates available are 24th. 25th, 26th and 28th January. That is a rather disturbing feature, if at the present moment I ask for teams to go out to take the oaths of people who have signed their forms in certain areas, I am told that the only dates that are available are those nearing the end of the last date for registration.

    I would urge Government to take steps immediately to see that more teams are available so that when we apply for dates for the oath to be taken, we can be given them instead of being told that we can only get dates just a few days before the close of the register.

10.39 a.m.

    Mr Hoffman: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am glad to be able to reassure the House that extra teams have been recruited and will be in operation shortly. We have based our extra teams on the calculation that we have made so far and aim at registering 300,000 persons by the target date if there are that many who will come forward. I can assure the House that this matter is very much in the minds of the Government and we shall take all necessary steps to see that everyone who wants to be registered as a citizen will have an opportunity to do so before the target date.

10.40 a.m.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, we welcome this Bill because it is the first of a series of steps to rationalise the foundations upon which we hope to build this State of Singapore. When I fought the last general elections, I could not help but think how stupidly obtuse the draftsman of the last Bill was in trying, by hypocritical legislation, to disqualify those born and bred in Singapore who have been away for three out of the last 10 years preceding the elections, although he allowed those, who were in no way connected with Singapore other than the fact that they had dwelt here for the last seven out of the last 10 years and made money out of it, to contest such elections. And the unholy spectacle of so many prominent Members of this Assembly taking their oaths of allegiance so late in the day is, I think, a salutary reminder to them and to the founder-members of the people of Singapore, namely, those born and bred here, that unless they rise up to their responsibilities then they deserve to perish.

    I am convinced that those born and bred here like myself do not intend to perish. We intend to fight and found this healthy and vigorous state which we hope one day will be part of the Federation of Malaya. And I would also like to remind all those who are enthusiastically applying for membership of this nation that it is not just a matter of going through the drill which the Registrar of Citizens assured me would not take more than eight minutes if efficiently done. He demonstrated it to me. I had the privilege of an actual demonstration of how a team of clerks could put a person through the mill in less than eight minutes, and I shudder to think what would happen if those eight minutes were the only impression which remained on the minds of the new citizens.

    It is the duty not only of the Government but of every political Party and every political leader to bring home the responsibilities and the meaning of citizenship, of what has so glibly been called "undivided loyalty". The test,
